entry.title: Clarification of basic RAP pattern
entry.content:
Hi experts,

We have a (probably) basic question about a recommended pattern in ABAP RAP model.

Context: we are developing a custom application with on-stack extensibility on S/4HANA Public Cloud. We have a custom entity ServiceMilestone, where we record the execution of a milestone for a service, that now needs to be billed. On this entity, we have a custom action CreateBillingRequest.

In the implementation of the CreateBillingRequest, we try to do the following:

1. Read the ServiceMilestone with EML based on the corresponding keys passed in the input parameter of CreateBillingRequest in a lt_servicemilestone local variable.

2. Create with EML a new entity for I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, using data from the lt_servicemilestone, assigning RESULT to a local lt_result, FAILED to a local lt_failed, REPORTED to a local lt_reported and MAPPED to a local lt_mapped.

3. lt_failed, lt_reported, lt_mapped are all initial after the EML creation, and the lt_result contains the CID and the fields of the newly created I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP. There is no ID generated at this moment yet for the I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, as it uses late numbering (key field BillingDocumentRequest is still empty).

So far so good it seems. If we do nothing else and just return from CreateBillingRequest, the LUW is committed successfully and we can see the newly created BDR in S/4.

But this is not our full need. We want to associate the new I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP into our entity ServiceMilestone. We created an association [0..1] in ServiceMilestone to I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP as BRD.

Our thinking here is (still in the call to CreateBillingRequest after steps 1, 2, 3): 

4. We have to somehow read the newly created entity with EML based on the data we got from the create (that we have in lt_result).

5. We have to add this information in the MAPPED output structure of the CreateBillingRequest, where we see that we have the ServiceMilestone field.

6. The RAP framework will commit the LUW, generate the document number for the I_BILLINGDOCUMENTREQUESTTP, save the association in our ServiceMilestone-BRD.

Is this the correct way to go or we are totally off? This should be a pretty basic pattern where a new entity with late numbering is created based on released interfaces and is then associated in our custom entity where we call the custom action.

If our way of thinking is correct, it would be great to point out how to implement correctly points 4 and 5.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: How to avoid creating condition records in SAP S4HANA?
entry.content:
In S/4HANA Private Cloud, what you’re seeing is standard External Services Management (MM‑SRV) behaviour if the system thinks it needs to store a price for later reuse. The OMFI default value (and the user parameter EVO) only controls whether prices from info records/contracts are proposed into the PO, not whether the system will create a new condition record when you save. That’s why your Z1 setting hasn’t stopped the ML35 record from appearing.

Go to your condition type in m/06 and see what settings is there for "Update" under Control Data. From your post, it seems, it is not blank. If you don’t want ME21N to create a record visible in ML35, set this field to blank for the relevant condition type in your PO pricing schema.

If your calculation schema includes a condition type with update control, it will trigger ML35 record creation.

If a service info record exists for the vendor/service combination, the system may be updating it when you save the PO. Check in ME12 (service info record) whether “Automatic creation” is active.

entry.title: Re: How to deploy Fiori to SAP S/4Hana Public Cloud using...
entry.content:
Hello @Mahesa_Lizardy 

No, it is not possible to deploy custom SAP Fiori/UI5 applications directly to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud from VS Code without access the Business Technology Platform or the Business Application Studio. The S/4HANA Public Cloud architecture only supports custom app deployment through SAP Business Technology Platform, using tools like Business Application Studio and does not provide direct transport or deployment interfaces for VS Code to the cloud system.

Develop an SAP Fiori Application and Deploy it to Cloud Foundry Using Visual Studio Code

In VS Code you can, develop your app locally using the SAP Fiori Tools extension, you can run and test the app locally. But for deployment you still need to connect to a BTP account, you have to use Cloud Foundry CLI or Fiori tools deployment command. Finally, you have to register the app to the S/4HANA cloud system through communications arrangements.

As a side note on why BAS is required. It is the official SAP supported IDE for extension in S/4HANA cloud. It provides the deployment pipelines, destination setup and integration tenant that VS Code cannot replicate by itself.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: VA01 payment terms input field value not getting reta...
entry.content:
Right now your problem isn’t really “how to skip the overwrite” — it’s “how to even see what the user typed before the overwrite happens.” In VA01/VA02, the payment terms field (VBKD-ZTERM) is filled from partner master data during partner determination and header/item data population. That logic runs before most of the MV45AFZZ user exits, so by the time you hit your enhancement, the manual value is gone.

In order to capture the manual value, in USEREXIT_MOVE_FIELD_TO_VBKD (MV45AFZZ), you have both:

  • XVBKD = current values from the screen
  • YVBKD = old values before the change

If you place your logic before you call any master‑data overwrite, you can compare the code. The trick is to run this in a point where XVBKD still has the screen value.

I can recommend the below debugging tips to pinpoint the overwrite

  • In VA01, enter your manual ZTERM.
  • Set a breakpoint on VBKD-ZTERM in the debugger (watchpoint: when value changes).
  • Step through — you’ll see exactly which form/FM overwrites it (often VBKD_FUELLEN).
  • Place your capture logic just before that call in the flow.

entry.title: Re: PPIO-ENTRY creates EWM stock transfer requests despit...
entry.content:
For information, PPIO‑ENTRY is essentially a background “order processing” program that can trigger staging proposals to EWM based on the production order’s component list and the staging indicator. In EWM‑integrated staging, the program calls the PP–EWM interface to create a Production Material Request or stock transfer request if it thinks there’s a shortfall in the production supply area. The background logic does not always aggregate duplicate component items the same way the online CO02 availability check does. This can result in a “phantom” requirement being sent to EWM, even though physically and logically there’s no shortage.

Please check the following

Go to LPK1 / LPK3 to check the control cycle for the material/PSA combination. Make sure the staging indicator (single order / release order / crate parts) is correct for your process. Inconsistent staging indicators between duplicate components can confuse the background run.

Check if the duplicate component items have identical item categories, supply areas, and storage locations. If they differ, the background program may treat them as separate requirements.

Go to SPRO → Logistics Execution → EWM Integration → Production Supply → Define Production Supply Areas and Staging Areas. Ensure the mapping is consistent for the storage location(s) in question.

Check OPJJ / OPJK parameters for availability check in production orders. The background job may be using a different checking rule than CO02.

entry.title: Re: CBC Baseline Scopes vs. Manual Selection – What’s the...
entry.content:
Hello @JuanseVal 

Adding to what has been said by @mpavan_kumar , 

The Baseline reflects SAP’s recommended starter set of scope items for your country/localization and industry.

Once the Baseline activation is concluded, you may extend the scope by adding additional scope items as required. However, i suggest you avoid removing baseline scope items during initial implementation.

Make sure you use CBC’s Scope and Organizational Structure phase to conduct proper Fit-to-Standard Workshops and capture your business needs. Thereafter you can add additional scope items if needed instead of removing baseline scopes.

Address any unnecessary or obsolete scope items via proper change management and additional scope activations and not by trimming the baseline.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Request to Merge Two Plants into One ERP Warehouse in...
entry.content:
In Public Cloud, the mapping between Plant → Storage Location → ERP Warehouse Number is part of the foundation organizational structure and is fixed once deployed. You cannot simply “edit” the mapping in CBC to merge two existing plants into one ERP warehouse number. This is because a plant is a legal/logistical entity in S/4HANA and is the top-level org unit for inventory valuation. An ERP warehouse number is always assigned to exactly one plant in standard Public Cloud WM/EWM integration. Cross‑plant ERP warehouses are not supported in Public Edition; each plant’s stock is managed separately in ERP.
On the implication side, to “merge” two plants into one ERP warehouse, you would need a re‑implementation or data migration to redesign the org structure — essentially closing one plant and moving its materials, stock, and processes into the other plant’s warehouse.

In Public Cloud, you cannot change the assignment in customizing (SPRO → Logistics Execution → Warehouse Management → Interfaces → Assign Warehouse Number to Plant/Storage Location) and it’s part of SAP’s restricted config. Any change would require an SAP Expert Configuration request and is only possible within the supported design rules (still one plant per ERP warehouse).

Below chart shows the difference between two scenarios

The recommended approach would be if the business goal is to operate one physical warehouse for two plants in Public Cloud, you must still model them as two separate ERP warehouses (one per plant) and manage them in EWM as two logical warehouses — even if physically they are in the same building. Cross‑plant consolidation can be handled at process level (e.g., shared resources, harmonized bin structures) but not by merging ERP warehouse numbers.

entry.title: Re: Distribution of AVC-objects
entry.content:
Hello @Florian83 

Good point, and thank you for the follow-up. Not all Advanced Variant Configuration objects are visible directly in the Software Collection app.

Key-user extensibility objects (custom fields, UI changes, and CDS views) are transferred via Export Software Collection.

AVC configuration objects, including characteristics, classes, profiles, dependencies, variant tables, and KB versions, are not managed in this location. Instead, they are transferred via the Configuration Transport (Q to P) within the CBC/SSCUI scope.

In this case, follow below;

Maintain and test AVC objects in Quality.

Run the configuration transport to Productive.

In Productive, perform a consistency check and release the Knowledge Base (KB) so the new rules are active.

The Software Collection app won't display AVC objects because they're part of configuration transport, not key-user extensibility.

SAP references:

  • SAP Learning-Processing Transports in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP Learning-Defining Knowledge Base and Runtime Version

Let me know if you need further assistance

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Regarding the method for calculating the fiscal year...
entry.content:
@Lakshmipathi 
Thank you for your reply.
I will respond to your inquiry.
If you require additional information to resolve the issue, please let us know.

・Why do you need to display the fiscal year — is it for reporting context, filtering, or calculations?
　→There is a requirement to display the fiscal year in the chart title.
　　The fiscal year is the newer of either the fiscal year calculated from the system date or the fiscal year calculated from a date obtained from a dimension item.
　　To meet this requirement, I first need to know how to calculate the fiscal year from the system date.

・Should the fiscal year be based on the current system date only, or on a user‑selected date?
　→It must be based on the current system date.

・Is the fiscal year definition the same for all company codes, or does it vary?
　→The definition of the fiscal year differs for each company code.

・Do you already have a fiscal calendar table in the model, or do we need to derive it dynamically?
　→Since the model does not have an accounting calendar table, it must be calculated dynamically.

・Should the fiscal year be derived from the posting date, document date, or purely the system date?
　→I want to calculate it based on the system date.

・How should the company code influence the fiscal year calculation — do different company codes have different fiscal year variants?
　→The fiscal year variant varies depending on the company code.

・Do you have a mapping of company code → fiscal year variant available in the data model?
　→Mapping is possible.

Thanks & Regards,
tsuuuu

entry.title: Re: Pricing - Condition activate with requirements
entry.content:
Hi @EdoTama ,

Pricing Requirements are executed at the beginning of price calculation. But in most cases they are not executed during price calculation. Therefore they are great for evaluating fields from KOMK or KOMP. But in most cases they do not work reliable for checking values that are calculated during pricing. In such cases I use a condition value formula instead. Within the condition value formula I set the Condition Inactive Indicator (KINAK). An example is SAP condition value formula 014 (ABAP FV64A014).

entry.title: Re: Scope items included in DDA but not available in CBC...
entry.content:
Hi JuanseVal,

Localization refers to whether or not the key legal requirements for the business process can be met via SAP Cloud ERP.
The ability to activate the scope item in CBC is independent of the localization - most scope items can be selected in CBC, but some must be activated via request to SAP via support ticket.

You can see the list of scope items that can be provisioned via CBC or not via the accelerator in the Roadmap viewer called:
Availability and Dependencies of Scope Items.xlsx (SAP Customer)
Column I of the scope sheet there shows whether it's available to be selected via CBC, and for example 1GA is not.
For non-CBC selectable scope items, you get them activated by requesting it to support on component XX-S4C-OPR-SRV

It's also worth doing a quick search of KBA's/notes if the non-CBC list above doesn't answer all the scope items you were looking at. E.g. 1GA also has some additional requirements e.g. it must be done in the initial phase as per this note:
https://me.sap.com/notes/3372903

entry.title: LE-WM is Ending: Understanding Stock Room Management vs EWM — What’s Next for Your Warehouse in SAP
entry.content:
Introduction

Warehouse Management (WM), part of SAP’s classic LE-WM (Logistics Execution – Warehouse Management) functionality, has been widely used in SAP ECC and S/4HANA for decades. However, SAP has announced that LE-WM is not the target architecture anymore. After 31 December 2025, LE-WM will no longer be usable under the compatibility scope in S/4HANA.

SAP provides two main alternatives:

  • Stock Room Management (SRM) – for customers with simpler warehouse processes.

  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) – SAP’s strategic, feature-rich solution for advanced needs.

    This blog consolidates SAP Notes and official guidance to help you evaluate your migration options.

LE-WM in S/4HANA: Compatibility Mode

  • SAP Note 2270211: “Warehouse Management (LE-WM) is not the target architecture anymore within SAP S/4HANA, on-premise edition. The available alternatives are Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM) and, since S/4HANA 1909, Stock Room Management.”

  • SAP Note 2577428: LE-WM is available in S/4HANA only in a compatibility mode until 31.12.2025, after which it cannot be used.

  • No technical migration is needed if you switch from LE-WM to Stock Room Management — but you must operate within its defined scope.

Key takeaway: LE-WM is frozen. For long-term sustainability, customers must plan for SRM or EWM.

Stock Room Management (SRM): The Lean Alternative

Introduced in S/4HANA 1909, Stock Room Management allows existing LE-WM customers to continue using basic warehouse processes beyond 2025.

According to SAP Note 2881166 (FAQ: Stock Room Management):

  • Reuses major parts of LE-WM but limited to elementary core processes.

  • Designed for companies that do not require advanced warehouse processes.

  • Covers functions like: storage bin management, goods receipt/issue, internal warehouse movements, physical inventory.

  • Does not include: TRM, VAS, Yard Management, Cross-Docking, Wave Management, or Decentral WM.

  • Included in the SAP S/4HANA Enterprise Management license (no extra cost).

Important: SAP has no plans to enhance Stock Room Management. Innovations and new features will only come in EWM.

Clarification 

“Stock Room Management is not officially limited to 2025, but innovations are frozen. For on-premise customers, SRM is the supported option beyond 2025, while for RISE customers, SAP has extended certain use rights until 2030 (see Note 2269324).

Compliance Check: Are You Eligible for SRM?

SAP provides a tool to check whether your current WM setup fits into SRM’s restricted scope.

From SAP Note 2882809 (Scope Compliance Check):

  • Run the program STOCKROOM_COMPLIANCE_CHECK in your S/4HANA system.

  • The report verifies whether your processes align with SRM scope.

  • If compliant, you can continue beyond 2025 with minimal changes.

Extended Warehouse Management (EWM): The Strategic Path

While SRM is a “maintenance bridge,” SAP’s strategic warehouse solution is EWM.

SAP Notes 2270211 and 2577428 emphasize:

  • New warehouses should be implemented in EWM.

  • EWM provides advanced functionality: automation, integration with material flow systems, cross-docking, yard management, wave planning, and more.

  • EWM is actively developed with continuous innovations and Fiori-based apps.

If your warehouse operations are complex, highly automated, or expected to scale, EWM is the safer long-term choice.

Comparison: SRM vs. EWM

Feature Stock Room Management (SRM) Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

AvailabilitySince S/4HANA 1909Embedded & Decentral (S/4HANA, SCM)
ScopeCore/basic WM processesFull-featured, advanced warehouse processes
LicenseIncluded in S/4HANA EMRequires additional license (except Basic EWM)
InnovationsNone (frozen)Continuous investment and enhancements
Best suited forSimple warehousesComplex/automated warehouses

Migration Roadmap: What Customers Should Do Now

  1. Assess Current Usage

    • Identify which LE-WM functionalities you are using.

    • Run the Scope Compliance Check (Note 2882809).

  2. Decide Between SRM and EWM

    • If your needs are basic → SRM may be sufficient.

    • If your needs are advanced or future-oriented → move to EWM.

  3. Plan the Migration

    • For SRM → minimal changes, but ensure compliance.

    • For EWM → plan a proper migration project with process redesign, data migration, and training.

  4. Act Early

    • Migration projects take time and resources. Start before 2025.

      Migration from WM to EWM: A High-Level View

      If your warehouse operations exceed what Stock Room Management can support, moving from LE-WM to Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) becomes the logical next step. Below is a concise overview + key resources.

       

      Stock Migration

      You can use this function to migrate stock data from LE-WM into SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM).

      Prerequisites

      • You have defined all the storage bins for which you want to transfer the stocks from LE-WM to EWM.

      • There are no open documents (for example, inbound delivery, outbound delivery, and so on).

      • You have created the handling unit types in EWM that also exist in ERP.

      • You have transferred the packaging materials that exist in ERP to EWM.

      • You have mapped the storage unit types to packaging materials (see Map Storage Unit Type to Packaging Material).

      • You have run the storage bin migration function and created all the necessary bins in EWM. For more information, see Storage Bin Migration.

      • You have run the warehouse product migration function for all products that exist in the stock being migrated. For more information, see Warehouse Product Migration.

      Features

      Direction

      • Download from LE-WM: The data is imported from LE-WM and saved in a file, taking into consideration the parameters specified in the following sections.

      • Upload to EWM: The data is available in a file and ready to be uploaded to EWM.

      Data Source

      ERP Business System specifies the LE-WM system from which the data is to be imported.

      Data Selection

      • ERP Plant (mandatory)

      • ERP Storage Location (optional)

      • ERP Warehouse Number (mandatory)

      • ERP Storage Type (optional)

      • ERP Storage Bin (optional)

      You can use the optional parameters, for example, to limit the amount of data or to carry out the migration in separate iterations.

      Conversion Rules

      EWM Warehouse Number specifies the EWM warehouse number to which the data should be uploaded. This entry is mandatory.

      File Destination

      • Local File: indicates if the file is in the local directory

      • Logical File: indicates if the file is in the application server

      • File Name: entry for the file name and its directory

      • File Type: the file type used by the report (only CSV files are supported)

      Display Control

      • Display Downloaded Data: When you select this checkbox, the data downloaded from LE-WM is displayed after import as an ALV.

      • Include Entries with Error: When you select this checkbox, data that contains errors (such as stocks that still have open documents) are included in the migration.

      Activities

      The function should be executed in two steps:

      1. Export the data from LE-WM and save it in a file.

      2. Use the report Initial Stock Data Transfer to upload the data to EWM, by selecting the Upload radio button. For more information, see Initial Stock Data Transfer.

      •  

      Key SAP Resources / Documentation

      For readers wanting to dig into the detailed technical and procedural guidance, here are useful SAP help links:

      • SAP Help for EWM version 9.0: general documentation and architecture.

      • Specific Help topics about migrating master data, warehouse product data, storage bin migration, and stock migration.

      • SAP Help sections that describe how to configure EWM, integrate it, and transition from LE-WM.

      You can find these via:

      • SAP EWM 9.0 help portal

      • Other EWM 9.0 topics (e.g. storage bin content, product master, etc.) via the help links you shared.

Conclusion

The message from SAP is consistent across Notes 2270211, 2881166, 2882809, and 2577428:

  • LE-WM ends after 2025.

  • Stock Room Management is only a stop-gap solution for simpler warehouses.

  • SAP EWM is the future of warehouse management in S/4HANA.

Now is the time to evaluate your warehouse landscape, run the compliance check, and plan your roadmap toward SRM or EWM.

Don’t wait — the earlier you act, the smoother your transition will be.
EWM - Basic Functions @ewms LE Warehouse Management SAP Extended Warehouse Management

entry.title: Re: Rebate and Royalties in SAP S/4
entry.content:
Hi All,

Business is not yet ready for rebate settlement through SAP.

I am following below setps to achieve the business requirement:

1. Create condition contract for rebate and set settlement date far in the future.

2. Include rebate condition type in SD billing but do not set accrual. It is statistical codnition type.

3. Collect royalties base value = Net billing value - rebate in billing Pricing procedure subtotal.

4. Create condition contract for Royalties and set amout field group in contract = subtotal of billing pric procedure (from step 3).

5. We are getting the desired result.

Do you forsee any challenge?

entry.title: Joule for Developers with SAP BTP ABAP Environment-Setup Guide
entry.content:
Introduction:

On average, an SAP ABAP developer spends approximately 2 hours understanding the functional specification before beginning the coding process. Depending on the requirement, complexity, and the developer’s experience, he may take a day or two or more.

Over the years, every SAP customer has invested significant effort in custom developments, extensions, testing, and optimizing the code. Imagine if the developer is on vacation or has transitioned to a different project; in such cases, new code changes or updates become a considerable challenge for a new developer to manage.

From my years of SAP ABAP development experience, I have worked on several internal and customer requirements with few to many challenges understanding the code. With the introduction of AI in the current trend, SAP has been one of the front-runners in introducing AI capabilities. Let me take this opportunity to introduce you to SAP Joule for Developers (in short J4D).

“Joule” is the SAP copilot that ABAP developers need for their development tasks. It is uniquely trained on SAP data and processes. Joule's ABAP developer capabilities combine all the features to support full-stack development with ABAP Cloud. For instance, Joule provides real-time explanations of development objects, streamlining learning and finding answers to questions. Joule is fully integrated in the ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse and provides accurate information about currently opened development objects or marked lines of code. Joule is also able to predict and generate subsequent lines of code based on comments, or the code you're typing. The Joule code prediction takes the ABAP language version of your selected development object into account and suggests ABAP code that fits the respective language version context. Joule can generate ABAP cloud development scenarios, including all required development objects.

Why Joule for ABAP Developers:

The AI capabilities for ABAP are designed to enhance developer productivity by delivering new generative AI-powered assistance for frequent developer tasks. The ABAP AI capabilities utilize a purpose-built large language model (LLM) trained on 250 million lines of ABAP code to deliver the most precise, contextual results for ABAP workloads.

Benefits?

Joule can understand SAP development framework intricacies, anticipate developers’ needs, offer intelligent suggestions, and automate repetitive, mundane tasks like documentation and sample data generation. It can enable developers across pro-code and automation projects to be more productive, creative, and proficient in accelerating apps or extensions for business applications.

  • Predictive code completion based on context, comments, and project heuristics
  • Code explanations of core data services (CDS) view entities, classes, interfaces, and functional modules
  • AI-powered assistance for documentation, best practices, and new concepts
  • Boost developer productivity

Here is a glimpse of all the Joule for Developers(J4D) capabilities that it offers:

 

What license is required?

J4D is a part of SAP AI Unit (8019164), - the new Per User Per Month (PUPM) license model released by SAP for all requirements. However, we also have a limited offer with Joule for Developers (8019124) limited promotion, which is valid only until Q2 '2026. For more details on the limited option, please refer to the Blogpost and take a look at the SAP Note: 3571857.

Joule for developers ABAP AI capabilities is technically available in SAP BTP ABAP Environment and SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition after the upgrade to release 2502.

After purchasing the license:

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment 
    All development tenants (where this license (8019164) is assigned/activated) in the corresponding SAP BTP Global Account are automatically enabled for the usage of Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities will show up only in one BTP Account where SKU is assigned.

Setup / Architecture diagram?

 

All requests to large language models are routed from ABAP to the AI foundation on SAP BTP. The use cases in the Accelerate category are managed by SAP. Once the subscription explained above is in place, the configuration part in your system is done automatically by SAP. Finally, update your ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse to the latest version using the link ADT version update to get the Joule integration in the IDE. Developers who shall be allowed to use Joule need the respective authorizations as explained in the documentation.

Use Cases: This documentation explains the ABAP development tools for Eclipse and refers to the range of functions that have been shipped as part of the standard delivery for the following products:

  • SAP BTP ABAP environment - If the user has ABAP SKU :8011136(Free), 8006181/8006182(Standard).  Use current blog steps to setup Joule for developers.                                                                                                                                                                                                           ABAP Service Plans-Service Plans and Metering for SAP BTP ABAP environment | SAP Help Portal, Know more-SAP Discovery Center Service - ABAP environment
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as of 2502- If the user doesn't have ABAP SKU as mentioned above, please use S/4 HANA PCE to setup Joule for Developers                                                                                                                                                                                                                   Setup Guide-Joule for Developer with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition-Setup Guide - SAP Community

Help doc: ABAP Development Tools 2502 GA Doc

Pre-requisite:

  • SAP BTP (Administrator role within subaccount)
    •  Joule Entitlements - please refer to license topic
      • ABAP environment-Standard
      • Cloud foundry
    • SAP Cloud Identity Services

Discovery center use cases (ABAP): SAP Discovery Center Business AI Features

Roles and Authorizations

To be able to use Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities, your system administrator must assign you to a business role that contains the business catalogue SAP_A4C_BC_DEV_AIQ_PC.

Joule setup via SAP BTP (ABAP Environment).

Create a subaccount in your Global Account in SAP BTP.

 

 Enter a preferred Subaccount name, Select the region as per the Joule supported Data Centre and click on Create.

Help Doc (Data centers):

Entitlements

Under Entitlements: In this section, we add different service plans.

Add service plans: ABAP environment

Add multiple quantities of 1 ABAP_COMPUTE_UNIT, 2 HANA_COMPUTE_UNITS, 1 standard.

 

We are going to use Cloud Foundry for our Joule developer capability setup. To do so, navigate to your Overview page within your subaccount and click on Enable Cloud Foundry, as shown below:

 

Create a space where instances can be created and deployed with the required roles.

 

Know more about roles: About Roles in the Cloud Foundry Environment | SAP Help Portal

 

Security: Before Joule can assist your developers, trust and identity must be configured correctly. Here’s how to ensure your system knows who’s who and what they’re allowed to do.

Under the security, Maintain Trust Configuration:

Choose the SAP Cloud Identity tenant for users when logging on to applications in this subaccount.

In this screen, please validate if the Cloud Identity Service URL is using the domain model, “*.accounts.cloud.sap” or do you see “*.accounts.ondemand.com”, select the appropriate domain.

 

Choose domain:

 

Configure Parameters

Enter the mandatory details: Name, Origin key, Text for user logon.

 

 Help Docs: Configure Trusted Domains in Identity Authentication | SAP Help Portal,

                         Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP | SAP Help Portal

 

Instance creation:

Under the space, create an instance of ABAP Environment:

 

 Create a new instance: Enter your instance name

 

Then, provide the email address (Mandatory) and system description in the parameter section.

Given Joule for developers is only supported in development; without this step, the setup won't work.

 

Note: At this point, this will only work if the same user whose email ID was provided under the admin email tries this. This is because additional users in the system haven't been created.

The instance is created.

 Click on the instance, it will redirect to a URL:

Note: At this point, this will only work if the same user whose email ID was provided under the admin email tries this. This is because additional users in the system haven't been created

Copy the URL: https://********* abap-web.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ - Here the region is EU, for your setup, the region can be different.

 

 Access Management:

Select Identity and access management from the dropdown:

Here, the User can add/delete the business roles.

 

 Add developer Role (SAP_BR_DEVELOPER) to the user: To access the ABAP developer functionalities.

Once, All the above steps have been incorporated, Goto ABAP Development Tool (latest version)

 

Create a new ABAP Cloud project:

 

Paste the URL Copied:

 Log on to the ABAP service instance:

 

 

Select the Default identity provider/ custom IDP created.

Help doc: How to setup a Customer IDP

After you log in: Success message will appear.

Your project is created.

 

Joule for developer’s capabilities.

AI-Based Feature

Description

More Information

Joule chat

The Joule chat supports you during the development process. Converse with the Joule chat in natural language, for instance, ask questions or obtain detailed explanations for code snippets or development objects.

For more information, see Chat.

Predictive Code Completion

The predictive code completion enables you to use AI-supported code completion in the ABAP source code editor.

For more information, see Predictive Code Completion.

Explain

The Explain feature enables you to get detailed explanations of selected development objects or lines of source code.

For more information, see Explain.

ABAP Unit

The AI-based ABAP Unit features are specifically designed to assist you in creating and improving your tests more effectively.

For more information, see ABAP Unit.

CDS Test Generation

The CDS test generation supports you in creating ABAP test classes for CDS entities.

For more information, see 

Generators

The Generators helps to boost your efficiency in generating unit test class for ABAP CDS entity.

For more information,

see Use CDS Test Class Generator | SAP Help Portal

Please look through the joule guide for more information: Joule Setup

Predictive Code Completion:

In the test class, create a new method like test_validate_customer_success (Positive scenario), try to create method test_validate_customer_failure (Negative scenario).

 

Press Enter: Application calculates predictive code.

Accept/discard.

 

 

 

 

In the search toolbar, search for joule:

 

 

 

 

 

In the joule pop up window:

Perform different operations:

 

Pretty printer the test class:

Joule lets the code modularize using pretty printer (Uppercase, Lowercase, spacing).

 

 

 Adding test cases

 

Joule helps to give some relevant test cases according to the code functionality.

 

 

FAQ’s: ABAP AI Strategy Frequently Asked Questions

Related Content:

Technical Announcement Blog: Joule speaks ABAP! - SAP Community

New landing page for SAP Joule for Developers: https://www.sap.com/products/artificial-intelligence/joule-for-developers.html

Thank you and regards,

Yash

(AI consultant)

SAP AI RIG Team

entry.title: Joule for Developers with SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition-Setup Guide
entry.content:
Introduction:

Typically, an SAP ABAP developer spends around two hours analyzing the functional specifications before diving into the actual coding. However, this time can vary significantly depending on the complexity of the requirement and the developer’s level of experience—ranging from a single day to several.

Over time, SAP customers have heavily invested in custom development, system enhancements, rigorous testing, and code optimization. This leads to a common challenge: when a developer goes on leave or transitions to another project, understanding and maintaining their code can become a daunting task for someone new.

Drawing from my own experience in SAP ABAP development, I’ve frequently encountered difficulties in interpreting legacy code—whether developed internally or for customers. In today's AI-driven landscape, SAP has taken bold steps to integrate artificial intelligence into its development ecosystem. One such innovation is SAP Joule for Developers (J4D).

    License (8019164) is assigned/activated, please be aware that it may take up to 24h after the process finished until all Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities are fully usable

Setup / Architecture diagram?

 

  • Joule is a software component, offered as Software-as-a-Service (managed, updated by SAP)​
  • Joule runs technically on the SAP Business Technology Platform​
  • A central, single “productive” tenant of Joule is recommended​
  • It can be instantiated multiple times, while a subaccount translates to a tenant. E.g. in case customers want to have a sandbox installation, or a separated dedicated Joule​
  • Respective tenants of SAP solutions (SAP SFSF, SAP S/4HANA Cloud) will then be “integrated” with a Joule tenant, manual process (“opt-in”)​
  • The Joule UI (Joule Web Client) appears then embedded within a frame within the connected SAP solution​
  • E.g. in case Joule is already set-up for SFSF the S4HANA system can simply be added to it!​
  • A central Joule tenant requires a “unified Identity and Access Management” (same IAS tenant for all connected SAP solutions)​
  • Current limitation: only 1 S/4HANA (Public/Private) tenant can be connected to a Joule tenant

 Finally, update your ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse to the latest version using the link ADT version update to get the Joule integration in the IDE. Developers who shall be allowed to use Joule need the respective authorizations as explained in the documentation.

Use Cases: This documentation explains the ABAP development tools for Eclipse and refers to the range of functions that have been shipped as part of the standard delivery for the following products:

  • SAP BTP ABAP environment - If the user has ABAP SKU :8011136(Free), 8006181/8006182(Standard).  Refer to Following blog steps to setup Joule for developers: Joule for Developers with SAP BTP ABAP Environment-Setup Guide - SAP Community            ABAP Service Plans-Service Plans and Metering for SAP BTP ABAP environment | SAP Help Portal, Know more-SAP Discovery Center Service - ABAP environment
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as of 2502- If the user doesn't have ABAP SKU as mentioned above, please refer to current S/4 HANA PCE Blog to setup Joule for Developers                     

Help doc: ABAP Development Tools 2502 GA Doc

 Pre-requisite:

Please follow the following process to enable Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities in the development instance(s):

  • Logon to SAP for Me.
  • Under Dashboards, please choose Services & Support.
  • On the tab Service Requests, choose the New Service Request button.
  • The system displays the New Service Request dialog. Choose the radio button Partner & Other Cloud Services.
  • On the service request home page, choose the Create Service Request button.
  • Search for "Toggle Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities" and then open the service request.
  • Use the service request to toggle the Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities and find the actual toggle status therein.

      Please be aware that it may take up to 24h after the process finished until all Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities are fully usable

entry.title: Re: How to set up FOC subcontracting process, without bot...
entry.content:
Hello @Deepika8 

On the Public Cloud, there's no direct equivalent of the Returnable Delivery Note (RDN) or Material Send Delivery Note (MSDN)

Posting Cancellations, Return Deliveries, and Returns 

transaction found in on-premises setups. Instead, you meet the requirement through the Stock Transport and Outbound Delivery processes, which are supported by movement types and document categories.

Returnable items: (tools, instruments, samples expected to be returned)

Use Stock Transport Order (STO) with the returnable flag.

Outbound delivery is created for the material, issued from your plant/storage location.

Movement type 633 for stock transport issue keeps visibility in special stock.

When the material returns, you post a goods receipt against the STO/delivery with the correct return movement type 634

That way, the system records that the goods were sent out temporarily and then returned, without affecting consumption.

Non-Returnable Goods (brochures, branding, consumables)

Use Goods Issue to Cost Center or Internal Order (movement type 201/261).

If a physical delivery note is required, you can create an Outbound Delivery without Reference (Fiori App Create Outbound Deliveries – Without Order Reference).

For stock transfers between service stations, use an STO without return -2891646 - Transfer Stock Cross Plant Create STO with one click missing TAB (consumption on receipt).

Calibration / Testing / Samples

Measuring instruments sent for calibration → Treat as Returnable STO (movement type 633 to 634).

Samples sent for material testing → Usually non-returnable (goods issued to cost centre/test lab).

Supporting Features in Public Cloud

Scope Item 1XN (Stock Transport Orders) – manages inter-plant transfers, including returnable flows.

Scope Item 2EJ (Intercompany Stock Transfer) – for instances where cross-company transfers are necessary..

Scope Item 3W3 (Advanced Returns Management) – for customer and vendor returns but not typically used for internal calibration or testing shipments.

Fiori Apps:

Post Goods Movement (MIGO functionality in Fiori, App ID MIGO_UI equivalent is not available – instead use Post Goods Movement – Fiori App F0843A)

Create Outbound Deliveries – Without Order Reference (App ID F0866A)

 Summary / Recommendation

Returnable → Stock Transport Order with return flag, outbound + inbound delivery, movement types 633/634.

Non-Returnable → Goods issue to cost center/internal order (201/261), or outbound delivery without reference for tracking/printing a note.

Use scope items 1XN/2EJ depending on whether same-company or intercompany.

There's no RDN/MSDN terminology used in Public Cloud; instead, follow the standard processes outlined above, using the correct movement types and delivery documents.

Let me know if you need further support

With kind

Chuma

entry.title: Re: We want hide some fields on va03
entry.content:
For information, in the Public Cloud model, flavor assignment is done indirectly via Assignment Categories and business roles, not by hard‑coding a user name.

So use Adapt UI → Screen Personas to hide the field and save your flavor. In the Manage Flavors app (Personas Administrator role), create an Assignment Category that will hold one or more flavors. Still in Manage Flavors, link your flavor to the category you just created. In Maintain Business Roles, add the assignment category to the role(s) that should see the flavor. This is done by adding the relevant business catalog for Screen Personas and then mapping the assignment category. Once the role is assigned to the user, they will automatically get the flavor when they open the app/transaction.

entry.title: Corrective Maintenance End To End Process with Material Management Integration
entry.content:
CORRECTIVE MAINTENANCE: -

In SAP S/4 HANA EAM the corrective maintenance process will start with the creation of notifications which involve malfunction or unexpected failures in equipment. In the corrective maintenance process, we will correct a malfunction or a machine failure by raising a notification and then the work order will be processed by the relevant technician. An authorized person in the PM system will approve and complete the work as per the work order.

Work process of corrective maintenance: -

  1. Identification of Issue: - Here in this step the maintenance notification for the equipment will be created.
  2. Evaluation and planning: - reviewing of notification, assigning of priority of the notification, based on priority a work order will be created. After the creation of maintenance order, it will be assigned to the respective task and will be assigned to the department or person.
  3.  Execution of corrective maintenance: - work order will be executed and if any materials are required then the materials will be issued against the work order.
  4. Documentation and data capture: - confirmation of work order will be done. (Max it will be done by production supervisor)
  5. Inspection and testing: - after completion of execution of work order the inspection will be done and a test run will be done.
  6. Completion and reporting: - TECO- Technical completion, the work order will then be completed, and no further changes can be made for the order. FICO consultant will settle the work orders at the month end.
  7. Continuous improvement: - they will just analyse the data, and they will try to find a solution.

MAINTENANCE NOTIFICATION: -

A notification usually refers to the technical object and contains the description and malfunction of the requirements. The starting point of the corrective maintenance is creation of notification.

IW21 --> Create 
IW22 --> Change
IW23 --> Display

After creation of notification, Now the production person will save it and then after the production supervisor will navigate to the machine and then he will decide the priority of the notification.

After adding the items on which the person needs to inspect then he will add the items that are needed to be inspected. And then we will just save the notification as well as we can release the notification too.
Then after we will create the maintenance order based on notification.

MAINTENANCE ORDER: -
It is a formal document in which the tasks, resources, specifications required to perform the maintenance activities on an asset, equipment or a specific location.

To create a work order
IW31 --> Create of work order
IW32 --> Change of work order
IW33 --> Display of work order

IW34 --> Creation of order from notification
IW36 --> Creation of suborder for a Work Order

STEP 2: -

Here we will provide the priority, order type, notification and the planning plant.

In operations tab we will just provide the no of hours, no of persons that are needed to perform the operations.

STEP 3: -
We can also maintain the relationships for the operations too. Here then after we will just add the materials in the components tab.

Relationship Type

Meaning

Explanation

FS

Finish--> Start

Operation A must finish before Operation B can start. Most common type.

SS

Start--> Start

Operation B can start only when Operation A starts. They run in parallel.

FF

Finish--> Finish

Operation B finishes only when Operation A finishes. Synchronizes the end.

SF

Start--> Finish

Operation A must start before Operation B finishes. Rarely used.

We will provide the relationships by navigating to the operations and select the operation then after we will just click on the enhancement.


Here based on our requirement we will just make changes for the relationship as SF, FF, FS, SS.

Then after the order needs to be saved. And we will just release the order.

STEP4: -
The materials need to be issued against the order. So, for this the material management (MM) team will be responsible for the issuing the goods.
To issue the goods we will use the t-code MIGO.

Here we will click on item ok for each of the materials and then after we will click on
check---> which will be used to check the materials if there are valid in stock or not and if material is not being activated all the properties of the materials.
Post --> which will be used to post the materials to the order after checking the materials and posting towards the inventory we can see that the material document number got generated.
After the materials are posted we can follow the path to check the material availability by clicking on the application toolbar.

Here after we can see that the material that are being withdrawn. If there is no material that is being withdrawn from the shop or else from the inventory, we can see them here in the availability list.

After withdrawing the materials, the technician will perform the maintenance activity and then the production supervisor will do the confirmation against the order.
STEP 5: -
The confirmation is done in the t-code IW41 a single order confirmation.

By selecting each operation, the confirmation will be done.

Here after just navigate to the change mode of notification and here just assign the activities of the task.

Here the activities are given and then after the times will be taken from the order.
STEP 6: -
Then after we will perform technical confirmation. we will just go and perform TECO – technical confirmation an order.


After clicking on the technical confirmation, we will just get a popup in which the completion confirmation information will be there.

Here we can observe the completion information of the order. And observe the status too.

Here after performing TECO no more goods movement will post, and no more operations can be done then after for settlement we will just navigate to the t-code KO88.

Here the parameters of settlement period, fiscal year, and then execute it.

Here by clicking on the accounting document we can view the details of the controlling as well as the accounting document.
Accounting Document: -

Controlling document: -


Below is the Complete Flow Chart if Corrective maintenance.

SUMMARY:- 

In summary Corrective Maintenance will be used in SAP Plant Maintenance when the machine or equipment is not working up to the mark, it means the efficiency of the machine is not as expected as it needs to be. And here in the above scenario I have tried to correct the machine which is not being performing well with integration part of SAP Material Management. In which the issuing of goods is being done from the inventory.

Any quires feel free to comment.

Thanks & Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Data Exports from SAP Business One for migration to Cloud ERP
entry.content:
When working with SAP Business One (SBO) and you need to integrate with other systems, for example integration flows. We need to have accurate data when exporting from SBO.
if you will use queries directly from HANA Studio or a MSSQL client you will not get the same format as we have in the SBO client. 

From my personal experience for optimal results and to avoid Malfunctions results, like NULL values and incorrect data formats. it's recommended to use the Query Generator in SAP Business One version for SAP HANA to extract the data. because the syntax is different for MSSQL, and can will be failed when running it on HANA.

Running your export queries within SBO ensures that the data is extracted in the format and structure that we have in SBO. reduces the chances of NULL Values instead of empty string. NULL Values can lead to unexpected data.

SBO handles data types and formatting (e.g., dates, numbers) in a specific way. Exporting directly from SBO ensures these formats are preserved.

To ensure that numeric values are parsed correctly in target systems. check that your thousands separator is a comma (,) (go to Administration -> System Initialization -> General setting - Display) and check your “Thousands Sep”. This is a common requirement for many integration scenarios to ensure numeric values are parsed correctly in target systems.
To have the correct Data Formats, set your date format to yy/mm/yyyy (go to Administration -> System Initialization -> General setting - Display) and check your “Date Format". Consistent date formatting is critical for accurate date.

We can use in the Query Generator to see the related table by the one in bold and add it to the query by drag it to the table section.

and ensure that we use the Correct Joins, to have all the necessary records and avoid missing data.
Incorrect or missing JOIN clauses are a common reason for incomplete datasets.
Double-check the relationships between tables in your query.
You can change the JOIN in the Query Generator (INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN) and select the one that retrieves all desired records for your specific use case.

One more thing that it is important is the Field Types and Lengths. We need to check if the data is match to the data Field Types and Lengths in the corresponding target systems.

We can leverage the SDK Help to get the Field Types and Lengths and check if we need to convert the data accordingly. it's highly recommended to use the SAP Business One SDK Help. This resource provides information on:

  • Field Types: you need to check that the data types of SBO fields will helps you choose appropriate corresponding types in your target system, preventing data truncation or type mismatch errors.
  • Field Lengths: you need to check that the data maximum length of a field is match to your target systems, if not you will need to check if you can truncate it accordingly and avoiding data loss.
  • Valid and Default Values: you can check what are the Valid Values for a filed and can use it in the query if needed
  • Related Tables: you can see the related table for a filed and can use it for join in the query if needed.

By following these best practices, you can improve the quality and reliability of your data exports from SAP Business One.

entry.title: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and Divisions) in SD Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hi, this is a common topic when designing the SD org. structure - we usually try to limit the number of Distribution Channels and Divisions to avoid redundant maintenance of customer and material master data in the sales view.

However, let's assume a case where we need to create 5 distribution channels (Wholesale, Retail, Online, etc.), but we don’t want to maintain thousands of material master records/sales views separately for each channel, especially since there’s no difference from the material perspective. Still, materials should be available via all channels in sales docs.

On the other hand, we do need to maintain customer master data for a certain distribution channel - due to specific master data, sales document settings, reporting, authorizations, etc.

It seems that the "common distribution channel" functionality, for some reason, can’t be used here because it’s not possible to define a common channel for the material master only.
(Similarly, it would be great if we could define a common division for customer master data only, but again... it's not possible).

Do you have any ideas or real-life examples from your projects on how to handle such cases?

Regards
Krzysztof

entry.title: Re: How to Post Exchange Rate Differences to P&L Instead...
entry.content:
In your case, why it is happening because, in Public Cloud, the way SAP treats the FX difference between GR and IR depends on:

  • Material price control (Standard Price S vs. Moving Average Price V)
  • Account assignment (stock vs. consumption vs. asset)
  • Configuration for “How Exchange Rate Differences Are Treated” (CBC activity)

By default Stock materials with moving average price → FX difference is capitalised into inventory value. Stock materials with standard price → FX difference posts to a price difference account (P&L), not to inventory. Consumption / service POs → FX difference posts to the same P&L account as the original expense, unless config says otherwise. If you’re seeing the FX difference capitalised even for services, it usually means the system is still treating the PO as stock‑relevant or the “Rate at Invoice Receipt” method is active.

Check your configuration and if needed, change that. In Public Cloud, there is a self‑service configuration activity. Activity ID: 104318 – Configure How Exchange Rate Differences Are Treated. Here you have two options - (1) Rate at Goods Receipt and (2) Rate at Invoice Receipt. Probably, currently, your set up would be Rate at Invoice Receipt. Switch to Rate at Goods Receipt if the business requirement is to expense FX differences to P&L.

Finally, ensure the PO has an account assignment category like K for cost center. So postings go directly to expense accounts. If you use a material master for services, check that it’s non‑stock and not flagged for inventory management.

entry.title: Re: Considerations on multiple Distribution Channels (and...
entry.content:
As you might be knowing, in standard SAP, the common distribution channel and common division settings in SPRO are global for both customer and material master data. If you define a common DC, the system will share both customer and material sales views across the linked channels. There’s no standard switch to say “apply common DC for materials only” or “for customers only”. That’s why in your case — where you want materials: shared across all 5 DCs without duplicate sales views and Customers: maintained separately per DC.  The standard config alone can’t give you that split behaviour.

So for your requirement, what you can do is define a common DC in config so that material sales views are shared. For customers, still maintain separate sales area data per DC — but control which DCs are actually used for customer master creation via:

  • Authorisation objects (V_KNA1_VKO, V_KNA1_VKO with DC field)
  • Data governance rules (MDG or workflow)

This way, technically the common DC applies to both, but in practice you only use it for materials. With this approach, an important point to be considered is this requires process discipline to avoid “accidentally” sharing customer data.

The other option is if you can’t or don’t want to use common DC, maintain material sales views in one DC and use MM17, LSMW, or Fiori mass maintenance apps to extend to the other DCs in bulk. Automate this as part of material creation workflow so it’s transparent to end users. Here, it keeps config simple, no common DC, but on the other hand, still creates multiple views in the database, but maintenance effort is automated
